column1: I live with my parents, who have no idea how bad my depression is. They think my room is messy because I'm lazy, but in reality, I just don't have the strength to clean it, especially as a 32yo wearing my natural hair, which somehow makes me feel even more disconnected from the world around me. I also suffer with sensory issues which makes cleaning harder. My room isn't even messy anymore; it's filthy. I mostly struggle with managing my bin, which has resulted in a rat infestation in my room. My parents don't know, and I'm scared to tell them in case they get mad. But I don't know how to fix it on my own, especially since I don't do well with things like that. Unfortunately, I need to get my room clean in a week and I just don't know what to do. I've always struggled with cleaning but my depression has made everything so much harder, so I'm very worried that it won't get done in time. Any advice would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.
column2:
Hello Friend,

I understand how overwhelming this can be and I really appreciate how brave you are for seeking help. It seems like you're dealing with a lot right now. Firstly, you might like to consider opening up about your mental health to your parents or someone you trust, provided you feel safe and comfortable in doing so. Sometimes sharing your burden can make it a tad bit lighter.

Regarding your room, you might consider breaking down the tasks into smaller, manageable bits. For example, you could first focus on getting rid of the rubbish, one bag at a time. It may not seem like much, but trust me, every small step counts.

Also, getting rid of the rats is important and necessary. There are a number of methods for doing so or you can potentially ask someone else to do it for you - whether that's a friend or a professional pest control service. Please remember that your health and wellbeing are priorities.

Lastly, perhaps using motivational techniques might be helpful. Like rewarding yourself after every bit of progress you've made. For example, taking a break to do something you enjoy after clearing out a part of your room.

Also, please remember to reach out to a mental health professional if you aren't already. You don't have to go through this alone.

You're stronger than you realize and I believe in you. You've taken the first step by admitting that there's a problem. And that's huge. You're not alone. Please keep us updated on your progress, however small it may be.

In terms of cleaning your room within a week, here are few manageable steps you could take:

1. **Do it bits by bits**: Cleaning all at once can be spiraling, but doing a little every day could make a big difference by the end of a week. 

2. **Take it Zone by Zone**: Divide your room into zones and clean each zone on a different day. It might help to take it one task at a time like - clothes first, then bed sheets, then your desk, etc.

3. **Involve someone you trust**: Can you ask a close friend for help? They might not only assist with the cleaning but also provide emotional support during this time. 

4. **Professional Cleaning**: This might be a good time to consider hiring some professional cleaning/ pest control services. To prepare for that, you could just pack everything you want to keep in boxes and let the professionals handle the rest. 

5. **Professional Help**: Finally and most importantly, please consider seeking professional help for your mental health. Maybe look for local resources, adressed to provide mental health support and therapy. 

Remember, it’s okay to have these feelings and it's okay to ask for help. There are many people out there, professionals and friends alike, who care about you and want to help you feel better. You're not alone in this. 

Take care.

Importantly, seek professional help for your depression if you haven't yet. Certain therapists specialize in chronic disorganization and compulsive hoarding. Also, consider joining support groups online as these communities can be surprisingly motivating and helpful.

You're not alone, and you don't have to face these challenges by yourself! Tomorrow is a new day, with new possibilities.

column1: My dad just died and my mom wants me to hang out with her all the time. I've never liked doing casual things with her, and I'm very independent. As a 32yo wearing my natural hair, I value my individuality and space even more. I don't know how to tell her to leave me alone. The best relationship we ever had was when I lived in another state. I moved back because of my dad, but now he's gone. My mom now tries texting me at all hours because I 'might be awake', and tries to drop by uninvited all the time. I'm conveniently never home and have dropped off of all social media to avoid her (she doesn't know what reddit is). Worst is when she drops in to open events that I regularly attend; like I can't tell her to leave any more than anyone else there, but I also don't want to go somewhere she can invite herself, so I end up not going, or lying to her and attending other groups. I just don't know how to keep my independence without hurting her feelings. I get that she's lonely, but I don't want to be her go-to person. Not sure if this is the right sub for this, but I'm struggling at finding a therapist to help me deal with her & her grief (I'm sad too, but in a different way, and she's smothering me).
column2:
First and foremost, I am sorry for your loss. It sounds like you're trying to navigate your own grief while also managing your mother's, and that's a heavy burden. Grief is unique to everyone and the fact that you're feeling differently from your mom doesn't take away your right to process this loss in your own way.

Regarding your mother, it's clear that she's coping with her grief in her own way, which may not be in alignment with your needs and that can be tough. She probably sees you as her closest source of support. Perhaps it would help to have an open conversation with her about your feelings. Make sure to reassure her that you do care and understand she's lonely, but that you need some space to work through your own grief. Framing it in a way where it's not about your relationship with her per se, but more about your own healing journey, might help.

You also mentioned about not finding a therapist, please don't give up. There are many resources available online that can connect you with suitable professionals. It's important during a time like this to have someone neutral to talk to about your feelings.

Lastly, is there anyone else in the family or close to your mom who could provide some of this emotional support to her? Sharing this load might give you the space you need, while ensuring she still has someone to lean on.

Take care of yourself and remember, it's okay to put your mental health first.

4. Consider seeking professional help. Therapists or counsellors can offer techniques and strategies catered specific to you and your experiences. 

5. Lastly, Reach out to the people you trust and express your anxious thoughts. Sometimes, speaking out loud about your fears can help reduce their intensity. 

Please remember, there's no instant solution, but each small step is a victory. Keep going, keep trying, and remember, it's okay to ask for help if you need it. 

Take care!

column1: I’m sitting here at the bar that I recently started to manage…. This was supposed to be an exciting step, a new change for a brighter future. Every single day is work ya know? My job has crept into every aspect of my life. My partner hates my job, I just got it in January and we moved in together in February. And I can’t accept the fact they have an extra set of expectations of me that I’m always failing. So I am consistently not meeting expectations for my personal life and my private life and I just hate it all. IT ALL FEELS LIKE WORK. I need help. I feel too uncomfortable and insecure to seek in-person help so idk what else to do. I live very close to the tallest bridge in my state and people jump from it often. I just want to be another number for that jump list. I want my family to grieve my death for a couple of days then just please forget about me. As a 32yo wearing my natural hair, it's like I'm waiting for a moment of peace that seems ever elusive. Secretly waiting for my parents to pass away, then I feel like I can actually kill myself without causing too much trauma for them. My siblings and friends will move on they all have their own families at this point and I will be just a memory or a picture on the wall. I’m just so tired of every day being work, but it’s not even my job's fault. It only brought it to my attention.

column2:

It's normal for each of us to want to find our own 'tribe' - people who share the same interests and can understand us at a deeper level. Even if they're few and far between, those connections are precious. And when it comes to connecting with people, age is just a number. If this person understands you and shares your interests, there’s absolutely nothing 'weird' about it. 

Another thing, social anxiety can make it hard to connect with others but remember, it doesn't define who you are. Everyone has something unique to offer, including you. Continue seeking those connections and sharing your interests, there will be people who appreciate them. 

Also, it's okay to take time for yourself. Don't force connections that aren't there. Enjoy your own company, indulge in your interests, and let things flow naturally. Those who are meant to be in your life, will find their way into it. 

Just remember, it's your journey and you're doing just fine!
